dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSH across a leaf-strewn lawn to find a GIRL, eight, wit long braids, staring at an abandoned Victorian house that fallen into grave disrepair. Shutters missing, paint peeling...an ingenue turned dowager by the march of time. Suddenly, a rock whizzes by the girl’s head and SHATTERS upper story window. She turns and we finally SEE her face This is ADELAIDE, and she has Down Syndrome. TWO BOYS, TEN, bash a gate open with a baseball bat and s into the yard. This is Troy and Bryan...the Rutger twins.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Hey, retard. They head into the empty derelict house, on a mission. Adelaide suddenly speaks.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. They stop, turn.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re going to die in there. They stare at her a beat, the moment is shocking. Then Tr runs to her, viciously pushes her to the ground. He regar her, spits on her, then heads back into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLASSICAL music plays. FLASHLIGHT BEAMS illuminate stunni Victorian fixtures as they are shattered by the bat. Lead stained glass, intricate moldings...the destruction is horrifying and complete, punctuated by the loud gunshot firecracker sound of SNAP and POPS the boys throw everywh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troy bashes stunningly beautiful leaded cabinets, shatter the glass. Suddenly, with alarm from another room --

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: Troy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are on Troy’s face as he slowly makes his way across t empty room. All we HEAR is the sound of flies...a faint buzzing, then a cacophony. He finally stops near where hi brother is standing and kneels down.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Awesome. He is looking at a dead gutted POSSUM...someone, somethin has feasted here. The possum’s face is frozen and twisted fear. ANGLE: the boys crouching reflection in the gray fl dead eye of the animal. Just then, a NOISE. Faint childis LAUGHTER. Adelaide? The boys investigate. They walk down the hall, when suddenly a BASEMENT DOOR at other end slowly creaks opens. The boys freeze, then --

dialogues.speaker: TROY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (afraid) Go.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: You go, shithead. A dare. Troy moves forward. His brother follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A murky soup, the flashlights cut a swath. The beams illuminate the odd stray cobweb, nothing much d here. The boys split up to investigate, Troy throwing the snap and pop. Until --

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: Check it out. Bryan approaches and stares with wonder. The flashlights illuminate a wall of dusty SPECIMEN JARS filled with yell viscous fluid. Within the fluid: monstrosities. Severed deformed hands, feet, a twisted jaw...a horrifying tablea the style of Joel Peter Witkin. Next to the jars: a neat line of surgical equipment. Clam disembowelers, spreaders...all caked in rusty blood. A moment of awe from the boys. WE SEE (but they don’t) something move behind them. A flash of white. Troy picks up one of the jars, studies, it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don’t. But Troy smashes it against a wall, it shatters.

dialogues.speaker: TROY
dialogues.text: It stinks down here. It stinks like shit. (beat) Last summer, when we had a raccoon stuck in the chimney? That’s what it smells like. Let’s go find it.

dialogues.speaker: BRYAN
dialogues.text: No, it smells bad. I’m going. Bryan starts off. Troy starts investigating, throwing the snap and pops. Bryan is half way up the stairs, when the and pops ABRUPTLY STOP. BRYAN (CONT’D) Troy? There is no sound. Then, a faint childish laugh. BRYAN (CONT’D) (freaked) Who’s down here! Silence. He moves down the creaking steps. Until his flashlight beam finds... Troy...eyes wide with fear...his throat ripped out. Terrified, Bryan feels something behind him. He hears a noise: breathing. He slowly turns, his beam ILLUMINATES: A blonde two year old BOY, wearing a Lindberg-era white christening gown with seed pearls long yellowed. His mout and face is smeared with blood, his skin is wrinkled like ancient man. The INFANTATA smiles, gurgles... Then ATTACKS. The lightlight falls to the ground. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: A SINGLE WORD POPS UP
dialogues.text: INT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE -- DAY THE SOUND OF RUNNING WATER. Come up on a TRAY of INSTRUMENTS.  A stainless steel SPECULUM, a large SYRINGE with NEEDLE, COTTON SWABS, COTTON BALLS, RUBBER GLOVES. The water stop and the hands of DR. DAY come into view. He towels them o pulls on the gloves.

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAY
dialogues.text: Are your periods regular again? He messes with the instruments as a WOMAN speaks. It’s VI HARMON.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Pretty much. Every other month. Dr. Day turns. REVEAL Vivien, gowned, on her back, her le in STIRRUPS. She’s pretty, forty, but she looks thirty fi

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not complaining. After all of that blood. Day inserts his gloved fingers into Vivien, beginning his exam. She takes in a sharp breath.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ben hates blood.

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAY
dialogues.text: How are you two doing? Sexual relations? Day is clinical. He’s not looking to get off here.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Sometimes. He inserts the speculum. She exhales. It hurts a little.

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAY
dialogues.text: You having trouble with arousal?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: A little. Thought maybe it was pre- menopause. He pulls out the speculum, takes off his gloves.

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAY
dialogues.text: Could be. Any issues achieving climax?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: I don’t know, it depends. When I’m alone it’s fine.  He nods.

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAY
dialogues.text: Well, things look great from a physical standpoint. Are you anxious about having sex? About something happening?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: You mean like getting pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAY
dialogues.text: It would be a normal response.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Well, I would like to go back on my birth control pills. He takes out her FILE. Writes --

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAY
dialogues.text: I want to wait a beat on those. They can cause irregularities in your hormone levels and I think you're already having some issues in that department. Your cycle, the sexual issues.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: I don’t have sexual issues. (then) Maybe I’m just depressed. Day takes a beat, then keeps writing -- that’s not his fi of expertise.

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAY
dialogues.text: I’ve recently had some success with women your age using bioidentical hormone treatments. Estrogen, progestin.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Wait, so I am going through menopause?

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAY
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. This is more of a pre-emptive strike. Your body is like a house, you can fix the tiles in the bathroom and the kitchen but if the foundation is decaying, you're wasting your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are there any side effects?

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAY
dialogues.text: The bHRT’s are great for your skin, your organs. Most of the women I give these to tell me they make them feel ten years younger.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: I don’t let my family use plastic bottles or hold their cell phones to their ears, now you want me to put something in my body and not tell me side effects? Don’t they make those things with horse pee?

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAY
dialogues.text: Feel and look ten years younger.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: The arousal issue is mine, not Ben’s. I’m just reconnecting with my body after what happened, I don’t want to give it away again.

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAY
dialogues.text: You’re worried about losing control, I’m offering you something to help you get it back.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: I’m not a house.

dialogues.speaker: DR. DAY
dialogues.text: Vivien, what are you so afraid of? Off Vivien, unsure of the answer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivien comes home with GROCERIES. Goes into the KITCHEN. Starts unloading. Along with the food is a LITTLE PHARMAC bag. She pulls out the hormone pills and creams, looks at them, thinks, then HEARS A NOISE from upstairs. A piece o furniture being moved? Her eyes go wide. Then, the sound again, longer, louder. She’s TERRIFIED, dials the phone.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR
dialogues.text: 911 operator, what is your emergency?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) There’s someone in my house.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR
dialogues.text: Are you sure it’s not a member of your family?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: No. My daughter is at school and my husband is at work. I think someone is robbing us. Someone robbed the brownstone next door two weeks ago. What do I do?

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR
dialogues.text: We're sending a patrol car. She hears a THUNK -- like a body hitting the floor. She hangs up. Thinks. Grabs a KNIFE and starts upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE: on the gleaming knife at her side. More sounds. Vi slowly makes her way to the door, takes a deep breath and CREAKS it open. On her face, the blood rushing out of it. GIRL’S VOICE (0.S.) Oh shit. Vivien backs out into the hallway, almost goes over the railing. She’s going to throw up. Before she can, her husband, BEN comes out, naked. He’s 42, fit, handsome as is pretty.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Vivien.... He goes to hug her. She instinctively SLASHES at him with knife. It SCRAPES his arm. Both of them look at the small yet real wound, shocked. She drops the knife. He takes he in his arms and keeps repeating with hysteria...

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I’m sorry I’m sorry... She lets him hold her for a beat, then breaks away in tea and runs down the stairs. Off a naked, bleeding Ben we SM TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DRIVING OVER THE GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE, SIX MONTHS LATER. Ha SUNLIGHT through the windows. Ben’s driving. Vivien in the passenger seat, staring out the window. Th fifteen year old GOTH daughter VIOLET in the back with si month old DOG, HALLIE.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Isn’t it beautiful?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: The light is different from Boston. Feels like I can see more. I thought it was supposed to be all foggy.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I need to go to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: It’s just a little while longer.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I need to go.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Where would you like me to pull over, sweetie -- the Bay or the Pacific?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: (re: the dog) Bet if baby substitute had to shit you'd find somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: I don’t like that word, Violet. A beat, then Violet looks out the window. Thoughtfully --

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Thirteen hundred people have jumped off of this thing -- at least that’s what they think. They don’t see them all and they stopped counting right before a thousand. I looked it up. Twenty six of them survived. You know what all of them said was their first thought after they stepped off? (then, mischievous) Oh shit. Her mother’s discomfort makes Violet grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of how I feel about this move. (then) I’m not going to like the school. San Francisco is filled with hippies and freaks and drug addicts.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I’m glad we named you Violet instead of our second choice.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Which was?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Sunshine. They all kind of crack up. A fleeting moment of family togetherness. Ben shares a smile with his wife, then reac out his hand to hold hers, but she PULLS it AWAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull into the driveway. Everyone takes a good look - it’s looking better than it did the last time we saw it. paint, shutters, gutters. There’s a FOR SALE sign on the lawn. All three of them take it in as they come to a stop

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: This is it. Vivien is unsure. Violet is intrigued. MARCY, the RELATOR greets them from the front porch with a WAVE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcy shows them around. The FOYER is epic, beautiful, soaring ceilings and a grand STAIRCASE. House porn.

dialogues.speaker: MARCY
dialogues.text: It’s the finest Queen Anne on the market. Venetian chandeliers, original moldings. The stained glass is some of the only of it’s kind that survived the great quake. As you can see the previous owners really loved the place like a child. They restored everything.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Gay?  10.

dialogues.speaker: MARCY
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, it’s San Francisco, they’re all gay. Light laughter. Except from Violet, who rolls her eyes. B sees this and fights a laugh. They head into the KITCHEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s beautiful. Looks original except with all of the mod bells and whistles.

dialogues.speaker: MARCY
dialogues.text: Do you cook?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Viv is a great cook. I got her cooking lessons a few years ago for her birthday and she ended up teaching the teacher a few things.

dialogues.speaker: MARCY
dialogues.text: Cooking lessons. Romantic. You're a psychiatrist?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Psychologist. You said something on the phone about there being a study upstairs that I could use as a home office? I’m planning on seeing patients here so I can spend more time with the family.

dialogues.speaker: MARCY
dialogues.text: How refreshing. Vivien shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hallie sniffs around, PEES in a corner, then SENSES SOMETHING. Explores, then -- STARTS BARKING LIKE CRAZY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet is staring out the window at the BACKYARD.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Violet, will you go see what’s going on with Hallie? Violet storms out. Teenager.  11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet finds Hallie, barking madly at the BASEMENT DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Shut up! She won’t. Violet looks at the door. It’s BOLTED SHUT. Ol school bolted. Two heavy bolts and two HUGE PADLOCKS. Someone doesn’t want to let anyone in -- or maybe out. Violet wiggles the doorknob, trying to pry it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the BOTTOM of the steps. POV of something watching t door move, the knob jiggle. We hear it’s raspy breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet tries the door a few more times, then yanks on the locks. No luck. She stares at the door, oddly drawn to it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcy shows Vivien and Ben the BEAUTIFUL GOTHIC LIBRARY.

dialogues.speaker: MARCY
dialogues.text: This is my favorite room in the house.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (to Vivien, trying) When I saw the pictures of this room online I thought maybe you could use it as your music room.

dialogues.speaker: MARCY
dialogues.text: You’re a musician?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: I was.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: She’s a cellist. She played in the Boston philharmonic. She heads over to the WALL. Something isn’t right.

dialogues.speaker: MARCY
dialogues.text: Why did you quit? There’s an answer, but we’re not going to get it.  12.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: This wallpaper is coming off. She goes to the wall, grabs a tiny PEELING PIECE of seagr wallpaper and gently pulls it off. It opens a small windo the ORIGINAL WALL, no bigger than a couple of postage sta

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think there’s a mural under here.

dialogues.speaker: MARCY
dialogues.text: The last owners must have covered it up. They were modernists. (then, with difficulty) Speaking of the last owners, full disclosure requires me to tell you about what happened to them.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Oh God, one of them didn’t die in here, did they?

dialogues.speaker: MARCY
dialogues.text: Yes, actually. Both of them. (off their shock) Murder suicide. I sold them the house, too. Just the sweetest couple. You never know I guess.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: So that’s why it’s half the price of every other house in the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: MARCY
dialogues.text: I have a very nice painted lady not too far from here but you’re going to get a third of the house for twice the price if you go that way. Vivien and Ben aren’t sure. Violet comes in carrying Hall

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Where did it happen?

dialogues.speaker: MARCY
dialogues.text: The basement. Another beat. Violet grins.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: We'll take it. Off Ben and Vivien --  13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As MOVERS finish bringing the last boxes in, Marcy pulls IN ESCROW sign off of the FOR SALE sign and replaces it w one that says SOLD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben comes out the bathroom in his pajamas, happy. Vivien still unpacking, there are boxes everywhere. He comes in behind her, kisses her, she gently moves away.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Come to bed, we'll finish this in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: I’m worried about Violet. She’s right about kids being different out here. She can’t handle another year of not fitting in.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You mean you can’t. (then) I treat kids like Violet every day. In three months she'll have lost all of the dark eye make up and combat boots and be walking around in Birkenstocks with unshaven pits smelling like patchouli. She laughs. He takes her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: It doesn’t freak you out at all? What happened here?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: My repulsion is tempered by the fact that this house is worth four times what we paid for it.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: But it’s not like some old lady died in here. A murder-suicide. Gives me the creeps just thinking about it.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: So don’t think about it.  14.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: That’s your professional advice, doctor?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: No place is perfect. No place and no person. (then) All I know is that for the first time in months I feel at home somewhere. Moving here, buying this house was the right thing to do for our family. It’s a good thing and frankly, we deserve some good after all the shit we’ve been through. (then, realizing) Sorry. She nods, not sure, but desperate to trust him. He kisses her. Another fleeting moment, this one of marital bliss, she can’t sustain it. She pulls away, leaves him to go do more unpacking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet walks through the commons, SMOKING. She surveys th scene -- a few kids reliving their grandparents’ Haight Ashbury fashion mistakes but most are unmemorable. Upper middle class high school in an upscale urban neighborhood She passes THREE pretty girls -- seniors dressed like the twenty-five -- talking up some boys -- LEAH, BECCA and AB Overhears their conversation --

dialogues.speaker: LEAH
dialogues.text: So I let him.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Do coke off of your nipples?

dialogues.speaker: LEAH
dialogues.text: They were numb for like two days. They all crack up. Violet tries to disappear into her swe as she passes, but --

dialogues.speaker: LEAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! Student council passed a rule against smoking in public spaces. The girls step in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Second hand smoke kills.  15. Violet puts the cigarette out.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I didn’t know. I’m new. Violet nervously flicks her butt into a planter. Leah fli

dialogues.speaker: LEAH
dialogues.text: What the hell is the matter with you? People sit here. They eat here.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You don’t know me. Why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Leah’s grandma died of lung cancer. She takes this stuff pretty seriously. Leah holds the butt out to Violet.

dialogues.speaker: LEAH
dialogues.text: Eat it. (off Violet’s shock) Eat it. Or I’m going to kick the shit out of you.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Come on, Leah, it’s enough.

dialogues.speaker: LEAH
dialogues.text: No, I want to see her eat it. She grabs Violet’s face.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Seriously, Leah, she’s like twelve. Leah starts trying to shove the cigarette into Violet’s mouth, but Violet resists, then instinctively SPITS in Le face. That stuns everyone. Abby and Becca can’t help but laugh. A beat, then Violet takes off running.

dialogues.speaker: LEAH
dialogues.text: (calling after her) You're dead! DEAD!  16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivien drops the NEEDLE on an old record player. Classica cello plays as she sets out her INSTRUMENTS -- a large bo of water, scraping tool, small knife. Slowly and carefull she starts removing the old wallpaper. As she does, the GOYA-ESQUE MURAL begins to reveal itself She can’t quite make out the first image -- until she pul off one more sliver or paper to see -- A WOMAN, her face in pain, her body twisted and tortured. Vivien stares at the image, transfixed and disturbed when suddenly a HAND touches her shoulder. She jumps out of he skin, turns, sees ADELAIDE, the child with Down Syndrome saw earlier, now a woman in her forties.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: You’re going to die in here.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Adelaide! Constance, Adelaide’s mother enters from the kitchen carr a BOX. Constance is a chain smoker, and she sounds like i CONSTANCE (CONT’D) Adelaide. I put that “Dora the Explorer” on for you so you would sit and watch it.

dialogues.speaker: ADELAIDE
dialogues.text: It was “Go Diego Go.” I don’t like it.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Brown cartoon characters -- you can’t tell the difference. Vivien doesn’t know what to make of this. Finally -- CONSTANCE (CONT’D) Hi. Hi. I’m Constance your neighbor -- the tear down next door. This is my girl Adelaide. Go home Addy. Now! Adelaide storms out. CONSTANCE (CONT’D) That girl is a monster. I love her and I’m a good Christian but Jesus A. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONSTANCE (CONT’D) Christ, if they’d invented some of those tests a few years earlier...

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: How did you get in my house?

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: You left your back door open, though I have to warn you Addy seems to always find a way in. She’s got a bug up her ass for this place, always has. You got a dog?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Yes. Is that a problem?

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Better for me. I run a little kennel out of my house. Doggy day care kind of thing. Don’t bother calling the cops on me -- I’m in with one of the city managers and he always looks the other way.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Look, it’s very nice to meet you but I wasn’t really prepared for company.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: I’m gone. Brought this for you, housewarming. Addy wanted to cook you a pie but she tends to spit in the cooking so I figured this was better -- should help you get rid of some of the bad ju-ju. She hands Vivien the box. CONSTANCE (CONT’D) Those homosexual boys were nice enough and I say live and let live, but I can’t help but think that that lifestyle drove them to do what they did. (then) I can’t remember your name.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: I didn’t tell you. I’m Vivien Harmon.  18.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTANCE
dialogues.text: Anyway, enjoy, relax, let me know if you need help with your pup. Glad you’re getting rid of that wallpaper. Thought those people were supposed to be stylish. She exits. Vivien can’t help but laugh a little at their oddity. She shakes her head, opens the box to see a TIGHT WOUND BUNCH OF SAGE. A beat, then -- through the window s sees Constance walking back to her house. CONSTANCE (CONT’D) (calling back) It’s Sage. For cleansing the spirits in the house. Too many bad memories in there.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Vivien moves through the house, the burning sage bundle i her hand. She’s not sure if she buys this whole cleansing spirits thing, but she’s committing. She moves into an

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS HALLWAY --
dialogues.text: She hasn't spent much time in this part of the house yet. It’s barely decorated and there are even a few EMPTY BOXE stacked at the dead end. Suddenly, the flame in the sage bundle is BLOWN OUT. Odd. She looks UP for the source and discovers a DRAFT coming from a TRAP DOOR IN THE CEILING. The attic. She puts down the sage, pulls over a chair. Standing on i she pulls the DRAWSTRING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOOR opens and STAIRS extend into the hallway. Common these old houses. She climbs in. DARKNESS, SILENCE. Her e adjust. Miraculously, she finds a LIGHT CORD, pulls it. The single bulb turns on and she’s standing face to face a BLACK RUBBER MAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben is on the bed, reading when he hears his wife SCREAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben rushes up the stairs, finds Vivien sitting on some ST of old newspapers.  19.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: What happened? Are you okay? She points to the rubber man -- he’s actually just a larg rubber suit -- known as a RUBBER ASPHYXIATION SUIT hangin from a hook. The suit is black, covers the entire body an has a mask with two small eye holes and two tiny breathin straws that can be pinched to temporarily suffocate the wearer.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Guess those guys were into the kinky stuff. (then) Should I try it on?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Stop it. It’s not funny. But they laugh. A beat, then Violet peeks her head in.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What happened? (seeing the suit) Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Get it out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

TATE’S VOICE I’m walking through the halls, I’m calm, I have the secret, I know what’s coming and I know no one can stop me, including myself. BEN’S VOICE Do you target people who have been mean to you? Unkind? TATE’S VOICE No. I kill people I like. In the hall, a SWEET INNOCENT 16-YEAR-OLD GIRL smiles at He smiles back. BEN’S VOICE Do you feel sympathy?  21. TATE’S VOICE No. I’m helping them.

dialogues.text: No. He RAISES HIS GUN, shoots the teacher. She instantly goes down. Tate looks at the shocked students, who are paralyz He starts roaming the aisles and just shooting.

dialogues.text: Some of them beg for their life, but I don’t feel sad, I don’t feel anything. Its a filthy world we live in, a filthy goddamned helpless world, and honestly? I feel I’m taking them away from all the shit and piss and vomit that runs in the streets, you know? I’m helping to take them somewhere clean and silent and kind.

Very smart. I like that. INT. VIOLET’S BEDROOM -- SIMULTANEOUS Violet cuts herself with the razor blade. She stares at t crimson gash on her arm with no emotion.

dialogues.text: Thursday’s better but I’1l1 make it work. She nods to both of them -- they both see different Moira and leaves.  28.

dialogues.text: One of my psych professors told me that people tell stories to cope with their fears. All art and myths are just creations to give us some sense of control over the things we're scared of. Afraid of dying? Create reincarnation. Afraid of evil? Create a benevolent God who sends evil doers to Hell. I’ve treated soldiers with PTSD by having them draw pictures of what happened over there.

dialogues.text: Violet won’t be home for an hour.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: No, Ben. Okay? No.  40. She pulls away. A beat, then he SWEEPS all of her tools a water off the table. He’s in a RAGE.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: How long, Vivien? How long are you going to punish me?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: I’m not punishing you, you narcissistic asshole -- I’m having trouble forgiving you for sleeping with one of your goddamn patients! You want me to have sex with you? When I can’t even look at your face without seeing the look on it when you were pile driving her in our bed?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I screwed up! I’m sorry! I was hurting too!

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, did the life you were growing die inside of your belly and did you have to carry that corpse inside of you? Did you have to go into labor? Give birth to your dead baby?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: My baby died, too! He was my son, too!

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: And you buried your sorrow in some twenty-year-old’s pussy.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I can show you statistics on how many men cheat after a miscarriage. I was there for you. I was patient and understanding and caring and I put your feelings first.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: My hero.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (so frustrated) I don’t know how to say this without coming off like an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never stopped you before. (then) You’re angry at me -- fine, yell at me. Six months in therapy of you crying and apologizing was all bullshit. Give me the real story now. A beat, and then it comes out --

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You got a dog! I needed you and you got a dog! It was me you should have been curling up with at night! I needed you. I was suffering and you weren’t there.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Now it all makes sense. She was revenge.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: We haven’t had sex in almost a year.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: You're keeping track?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: October 20th. And we had great sex, Viv. It was loving and sexy and personal and even a little...weird. She laughs lightly through her tears.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love you. I moved across the country for you because in all my life the only thing I’ve been truly scared of is losing you. Losing this family. (then) Something horrible happened to us. More horrible than anything on this wall and then we handled it even more horribly. But this place is our second chance. It’s not supposed to happen overnight but it’s like this wallpaper, a little bit at a time. I just need to know that you want it, too.  42. She looks up at him, her eyes wet. She can’t move. Wants run to him but she’s paralyzed by the fear of being vulnerable to him again. He makes his move, kisses her. She’s overwhelmed. His tou finally letting herself feel it after so long. Both of them crying as they fall to the floor. Kissing. Clothes coming off. Buckles and zippers fumbled with. There, on the floor, they make love again. As they both r climax, we CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the floor, post coitus. Him behind her. She’s looking at the wall.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Thanks. (off his look, smiling) Not for the sex, idiot.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (kissing her neck) For what, then?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Giving up your practice, moving us out here, finding this house.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I want you to feel chosen. She pulls him close.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: I always wanted a house like this growing up. You’ve been to my parents house out on the Island. Post war prefab hell. The whole place rattled when you walked down the hall. I used to dream about old places like this. A place with a soul.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: What do you want to do about this wall?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: I know it’s disturbing...like, deeply disturbing. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I don’t know...something about it inspires me.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: To pillage a small hamlet?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: To make art again...to play again. That gets his attention. Forget the sex, her playing musi again would be a true breakthrough.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Your cello is up in the attic. You want me to get it down for you?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Relax, cowboy. If I want it, I’1l get it down myself. They share a smile, kiss.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I really think we’re going to be happy here.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivien straightens up, hopeful for the first time in a lo time. Violet tries to sneak by unseen, fails.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: What happened to your face?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I fell down. Vivien stops her, takes a good look. She’s a mess.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: (kind) Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: If you don’t clean those up properly they’1ll get infected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Vivien grabs a FIRST AID KIT, runs hot water on som hand towels, sits. Tends to Violet.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Was it a girl or a boy?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Girls. Three of them.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Hope they look worse. You know their names?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’m not narcing. Vivien just keeps at the cuts and scrapes. A quiet beat. Just a mother taking care of her daughter’s boo-boos.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: You want dad and I to look into switching schools? There are some good private schools in the area.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’m not running away -- I’m not scared of them.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: You’re not scared of anything. When you were in kindergarten you had me come pick you up from a sleepover party because the other girls insisted on keeping a night light on. Violet almost smiles.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got the short end of the stick with this one, kiddo. The move. Dad and I have been pretty hard to live with for a while now.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I just don’t get why you guys won't get divorced if you’re so miserable.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: We still love each other.  45.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Really? Could have fooled me. I thought you hated each other -- well, at least you hated him. I don’t blame you. He was a shithead. (realizing) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: It’s all right -- he was a shithead. Shared smiles. Vivien finishes up. Violet starts out, tur

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What are you scared of? You said I’m not scared of anything. But what scares you?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Everything. (then) That’s why we’re not getting a divorce. You’re dad’s the only one who keeps me from feeling afraid all the time. Violet gets it, exits. Off Vivien -- INT. VIOLET’S ROOM -- DAY (LATER) Violet is pacing, in a teenage rage. Tate quietly watches she spews.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I hate her. I want to kill her.

dialogues.speaker: TATE
dialogues.text: Then do it. One less highschool bitch in the world making the lives of the less fortunate more tolerable is, in my opinion, a public service. Violet pauses, then laughs. He breaks her mood. She light a joint, inhales, hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: TATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No thanks. I like to stay pure.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Why?  46.

dialogues.speaker: TATE
dialogues.text: I want to feel what I’m feeling. A moment of connection, then --

dialogues.speaker: TATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, you want her to leave you alone? Stop making your life a living hell? Short of killing her, there’s only one solution: scare her. Make her afraid of you, that’s the only thing bullies react to.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: TATE
dialogues.text: It’s simple. You simply walk up to her and say --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leah is whirled around by a calm Violet.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Here’s the deal. I need you to stop harassing me. I’ve got what you want. Drugs. Come to my house tomorrow, get your free sample. I’m a dealer, and a good one. I’ve got the best shit in town. Violet smiles darkly, leaves. Leah is intrigued. INT. VIOLET’S ROOM -- DAY

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: She’s a cokehead. I don’t have coke.

dialogues.speaker: TATE
dialogues.text: You won’t need it. That’s just an excuse to get her here. She’1l leave empty handed and terrified and I promise you, you’1ll never be bothered by her again.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: How am I gonna terrify her?

dialogues.speaker: TATE
dialogues.text: That’s where I come in. He smiles sexily. She laughs. It’s a plan.  47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUIET. The clock on the wall TICKS from twelve-ten to twe eleven AM. MOVE THROUGH THE HOUSE --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lit by a single LAMP. The silence broken by Vivien’s excessive SCRAPING. She peels off the LAST SCRAP of wallpaper. Stands back to take in the WALL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben has fallen asleep reading. His eyes OPEN. The same unconscious zombie-like awake he was the night of the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLOW PULL BACK to finally reveal...The WALL -- if the Ant Christ had a Sistine Chapel, this is what would adorn the ceiling. It’s a painted prayer to PAIN. Vivien is oddly undisturbed by the images of torture, murder, RAPE. As she loses herself in the mural we see Ben SLEEPWALK be her, unseen, into the KITCHEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, at the stove. TURNS ON THE BURNERS -- all of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TOILET FLUSHES and Vivien, in her pajamas, comes out of bathroom, rubs lotion on her arms. Ready for bed. She looks up, jumps when she sees THE RUBBER MAN standing silently in the doorway. A beat, then a smile --

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Hot. I thought I told you to throw that thing away. The Rubber Man is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben leans down. Eye level with the BLUE FLAMES. They HISS He reaches his hand out.  48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rubber Man just stands there. Vivien laughs.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: I have to admit, I’m giving you points for creativity. (then) You were pretty hot this afternoon. Wanna go for a two-peat? She gets into bed. Pulls off her pajamas. Rubber Man move towards her.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You going to take the suit off? (off his head shake “no”) Okay, whatever, I can be kinky. The Rubber Man approaches, RIGHT INTO CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben lowers his hand, into the flames. It BLISTERS, CRACKS No response. Like it’s happening to someone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rubber Man, on top of Vivien. FUCKING HER. It feels s good, but it HURTS -- not just physically. She can feel t darkness of the Wall inside of her. Her head is back, a t rolls down her cheek. He FINISHES and stops moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben’s hand is being burned by the flames. His flesh bubbl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rubber Man is gone. Vivien pulls up her pajama pants. She’s emotional, vulnerable. Gets under the covers, turns the light as Ben enters, still SLEEPWALKING. He gets into bed. She rolls over. On her face.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Good night. I love you. Ben stares off into space.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Love you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand pushes open the gate. REVEAL Leah, who stops and stares at the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivien takes her cello out of its case, looks at it. She hesitates, sits with it, slowly begins to play a John Cag solo. It’s passionate, full of all her unexpressed feelin An exorcism. INTERCUT the dramatic bowing of her cello wi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the bottom of the stairs, looking UP at the door. Th sounds of muffled talking. The locks being UNLOCKED. The opens. Violet and Leah look down from above.

dialogues.speaker: LEAH
dialogues.text: What’s down there?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: My stash. My parents toss my room every week. Leah’s not sure. Violet, playing it cool, starts down.

dialogues.speaker: LEAH
dialogues.text: If you’re screwing with me... Violet disappears down the stairs. Leah does NOT want to down there. Violet reaches the bottom -- turns --

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: It’s just a basement. Fuck it. Leah comes down. Leah’s POV, following Violet.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I found the best hiding place. This is great shit, too. A lot of the coke coming into the US from Central America is smuggled in on lobster boats in Gloucester. I used to show my boobs to one of the lobsterman in return for a key or two before they cut it. They come around a corner, find TATE, sitting on a RUSTED MEAT FREEZER.  50.

dialogues.speaker: LEAH
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: TATE
dialogues.text: So this is the coke whore. SLOW MOTION -- Leah looks eyes with Violet. She can see i Violet’s face -- things are about to get scary for her. S flees. Too slow. Tate grabs her.

dialogues.speaker: TATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Violet) Get the light! Violet TURNS OFF the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivien’s solo moves toward a crescendo. The bow almost bu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it’s just sounds. Leah fighting. Tate laughing.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: It’s enough, Tate. Violet’s BUMPED to the ground. We can hear the wind being knocked out of her. Leah’s screams become more desperate.

dialogues.speaker: LEAH
dialogues.text: Oh, God! Get it off of me! Please God get it off of me!

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What’s happening? Tate it’s enough! Violet fumbles for her cell phone as screams continue. Tu on her NIGHT VISION APP. SEARCHES for Leah with the phone Finds her. There’s something on attacking her. The thing turns. It’s the INFANTATA. It HISSES at Violet. Violet SCREAMS, shocked, the phone falls to the floor, we her kick her way to the wall. Turns on the light. Nothing here now. It’s all happened in milli-seconds. Leah scampers to her feet. Her face is slashed. CLAW MARK She runs up the stairs, out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: TATE
dialogues.text: I don’t think she'll be bothering you anymore.  51. He goes to Violet. She backs away.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What was that? Something was on her. What did you put on her?

dialogues.speaker: TATE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? She kneed me in the balls and got away. She must have run into a wall or something.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I saw something. With my phone. It was like a monster or something.

dialogues.speaker: TATE
dialogues.text: You're talking crazy. Violet, this is cool. We just showed that bitch.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Get out. I don’t want to see you again. He tries to hug her. She backs away, moves up the stairs, never taking her eyes off of him. She’s going to CRY.

dialogues.speaker: TATE
dialogues.text: (deadly) I thought you weren’t afraid of anything. She doesn’t like this guy anymore. She TRIPS backing up t stairs, gets her footing and runs out. Off Tate, a devili grin on his face....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivien finishes. She’s flushed and smiling, this was a personal triumph for her. She hears the front screen door slam -- Leah exiting. Off Vivien, enjoying a moment of ra happiness -- INT. SAN FRANCISCO DOCTOR’S OFFICE -- DAY TIGHT on blood filling a syringe. As the draw continues -

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Agitation, difficulty sleeping...anything else? REVEAL Vivien, having her blood drawn, talking to a new physician, DR. EMILY FLEMING.  52.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: A little trouble sleeping, yes.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FLEMING
dialogues.text: Any hallucinations?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FLEMING
dialogues.text: The hormone cocktail you are on can sometimes cause hallucinations, euphoria...

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: No. No hallucinations.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FLEMING
dialogues.text: How long have you been taking it?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: A couple of weeks?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FLEMING
dialogues.text: Any sexual activity?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: Yes. Finally. It’s helped with that. Another laugh. The doctor finishes the blood draw.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FLEMING
dialogues.text: Okay. Well we’ll do a blood panel, see what’s going on. The doctor calms Vivien, who nods. Everything's going to okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet enters, apprehensive. Abby and Becca -- Leah’s bud -- come up and surround her.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: What did you do to Leah? Violet is ready to rumble.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I didn’t do anything.  53.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Bullshit. Something happened to her at your house. Violet tenses her fist. It’s about to go down.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: So it was awesome! She totally dropped out of school, you terrorized her! Great job. The girls are laughing.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I thought you were her friends.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: We hung out with her because her parents were always away so we could party at her house.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Killer pool.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: She was a total bitch.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Hard core.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Anyway. We’re hitting up The Bagel after school. It’s a pretty cool deli down in the Mission if you want to come. A lot of the kids from here go there.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: Serious dude-age.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Sounds all right. Should I meet you?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: No, I got my dad’s car. We're be out front at three. Violet nods. The girls heads off. As they go --  54.

dialogues.speaker: BECCA
dialogues.text: You think I could pull off that Taylor Momsen black eye shadow thing? Violet takes it all in, smiles. Holy crap -- she has frie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben stretches. Ready for a RUN. Senses something. He covertly turns. Spies the BURNT MAN in a car, lurking. A beat, then Ben starts his run. The car pulls out, followi him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben runs into GOLDEN GATE PARK. The Burnt Man follows. Parks. Continues on foot. He’s slow, but he cuts through TREES to keep up. Ben SPEEDS UP. Runs out of frame. We’re with the Burnt Ma now. Out of breath. Searching for Ben. He’s lost him, the Ben grabs him. Spins him around violently.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Who are you? Why are you following me?! The Burnt Man cowers. We can see how old he is now, vulnerable, afraid.

dialogues.speaker: BURNT MAN
dialogues.text: Please. Your family is in danger. Ben calms. Backs off. After a beat we CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bench underneath the Bridge. Ben sits beside the Burnt Man. We get a good look at him now -- his face is mangled so are his hands. Burns that severe can’t heal. The Burnt notices Ben’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: BURNT MAN
dialogues.text: What happened to your hand?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: What happened to your face?

dialogues.speaker: BURNT MAN
dialogues.text: It’s not just my face. Seventy percent of my body. You don’t survive something like that -- and this was the sixties. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BURNT MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (then) I’m Larry Harvey -- and you have to get out of that house.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I could have you arrested, you know? Peeking in peoples’ windows is a crime -- even in San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: They’re not going to put me back in jail. I have brain cancer -- terminal and inoperable.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Don’t be. That’s the only reason they let me out. (a beat) Homicide. Triple homicide. San Quentin for forty-two-years without a cold then two months ago they diagnose me with these tumors in my head. Some people would call that fate.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: God gave you cancer so you could get out of prison and tell me to move?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Maybe. I don’t know. I’ve seen stranger things.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Sounds more like a man who is searching for a chance at redemption for the awful things he’s done. Larry chuckles. There’s no redemption for him. He pauses, then looks at Ben directly.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I made it six months in the house you live in now before I started hearing the voices. My wife thought I was working too hard. My daughter Angie -- she was six. The older one Margaret was ten. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Looked like her mother. Funny how it skips a generation like that.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Look, I get that you’re lonely and you're struggling. Getting out of prison after all of those years. I’m sure...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I killed them all. Off Ben, shocked we FLASH TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CAN OF GASOLINE. Larry's carrying it up the stairs. Ina trance.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Loraine was ill that night. My wife. She took a pill and went to bed early. I put the girls down. Then the voices started. We see him enter his children’s room -- INT. KIDS’ ROOM -- NIGHT He pours the GASOLINE.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: They told me what to do. I was like an obedient child. We're on his face. His eyes are BLACK. DEAD. He lights a match. TOSSES it. Stay on his face as the FLAMES illumina the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry gives his wife the same treatment. He watches her BURN. Then, suddenly, she SPRINGS UP. Engulfed in flames. SCREAMING. She grabs him. He snaps out of it. Realizes wh he’s done. It’s too late. He throws her off but now he’s FIRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLOW MOTION as Larry, a ball of fire, runs down the stair

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And through the living room, past the MURAL.  FLASH BACK TO --—
Ben is shocked. Larry is crying. He takes a beat.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I don’t know how I put the myself out. I remember the night, but it’s like a movie. Have you been sleepwalking? The question hits Ben hard. LARRY (CONT’D) I’ve seen your family. Pretty wife. You seem like good people. If you don’t get out of that house you’re all going to die in there.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: There are some pretty serious side effects to brain tumors. People hallucinate, act strangely, invent whole worlds in their heads.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Look up my case. Read the transcripts. Ben gets up.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I’m a doctor. They might not put you back in jail but I could certainly get you committed to a state mental institution. Trust me, those places make prison look like Club Med. Leave my family alone. Larry jumps up, desperate.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Please. Please get out of there. That place is evil.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Get off of me! I’m not kidding, leave us alone. Ben starts off. A beat before Larry calls after him --  58.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You never answered me -- what happened to your hand? Ben looks down at his hand. Fear plays across Ben’s face before he jogs off -- speeding up as he goes. INT. BEN’S HOME OFFICE -- DAY A LOCK is picked. Reveal Violet, on a mission. She feveri goes through a drawer, looking for a patient file. She finds Tate’s, pulls it, exits. INT. VIOLET’S ROOM -- DAY Violet pours over the information. She is riveted by word her father has used to describe his patient. TIGHT ON THE SOCIOPATH...MURDER FANTASIES...VIOLENT. Violet pauses. She goes to her computer, types Tate’s nam Google search. A beat. Her eyes goes wide. REVEAL a flurry of headlines. “Student, 17, Kills Fifteen in San Francisco Bloodbath.” “Shooter described as ‘Charming’ and ‘A Loner.’ There are several photos of grieving parents, and a schoo picture of Tate. Finally, Violet gasps. Another headline: “Student Takes Own Life After High School Massacre.” REVEAL the year of the shootings: 1994. Tate died seventeen years ago. Off Violet --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben sits at the table, stunned, shaken. Vivien enters, co up behind him, kisses him. It comforts him. He hides his burnt hand under the table.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: What do you want for dinner?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Whatever Violet wants.  59.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIEN
dialogues.text: She’s going out with some friends. They share a look -- really? Ben smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
